pages.text: A staple of early civilizations. $(thing)Earthenware, stoneware and ceramics$() have a variety of uses such as enabling advanced manufacturing, strong materials, storage and decoration.

The ware crafting station is a simple workshop, using an $(item)Artisan Carver$(), it will aid me in working with soft materials, molding and sculpting; however, if I ever want to $(thing)automate$() any of these processes, I should look into a $(item)Turntable$().$(br2)The basic premise of sculpting starts with a full block of material, by carving and smoothing out different segments I can create quality recipients or intricate shapes.

After acquiring the material block, I just have to sculpt it directly with my $(item)carver$() until I get the desired shape, the resulting product should be able to be $(thing)fired$() in a $(l:innovation/kiln)kiln$(). What follows is a list of the different devices I believe I'm able to craft, most of which are made by continuing to work on the previous one.

pages.title: Planter
pages.text: Made from a single block of clay, the $(item)planter$() is a powerful device which lets me plant crops safely indoors without needing a water source nearby. Although it would be a bit tedious to create a large scale farm using only these.

pages.title: Pot
pages.text: Made from an unfired $(item)planter$() as a base, a $(item)pot$() is a simple ware, useful for storing items, as well as aesthetically pleasing, I can come up with a small variety of designs for these.

pages.title: Vase
pages.text: Made from an unfired $(item)pot$() as a base, a $(item)vase$() is a small container with a thin neck; it can hold $(thing)one$() item at a time, although I will not be able to retrieve said item without breaking the vase... I should be careful with stuff like $(item)Blasting oil$() slipping into one...

pages.title: Urn
pages.text: Made from an unfired $(item)vase$() as a base, the $(item)urn$() is one specific ware usually reserved for funerary purposes (or holding tea!). Nonetheless, I may have come with a more obscure utility for it... further research is needed.

Of course, there are several items, blocks and such which do not require so much as a specialized workbench to be manufactured, but may be just as useful. After all, such malleable materials can be manipulated in more than one way.

Rather rudimentary, yet effective. If I can put several of these together and harden them, I may be able to create a set of clay plate armor. It would be rather heavy, but certainly tougher than average armors.
More durable than a wooden bucket, it will still break if carrying hot fluids.
